questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi palsy, and loss of corneal sensation. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium leprae

 

Based on the ocular manifestations of leprosy, Mycobacterium leprae is the most likely causative organism.

 

  • Ocular symptoms include:
    • Lagophthalmos (inability to close the eyelids) due to the involvement of the zygomatic branch of the facial nerve. Other causes of lagophthalmos include extreme proptosis (bulging of the eyes) and symblepharon (adhesion of the eyelids to the eyeball).
    • Corneal anesthesia is due to the involvement of the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve, which innervates the cornea.
    • Corneal ulceration
    • Episcleritis
    • Iris atrophy
  • In addition, patients may present with:
    • Cataract,
    • Glaucoma,
    • Madarosis (loss of eyelashes or eyebrows)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Acanthamoeba castellanii

 

  • Acanthamoeba castellanii can cause acanthamoeba keratitis.
  • Symptoms include pain, lacrimation, photophobia, and foreign body sensation.
  • Results from direct corneal contact with infected material.
  • Contact lens users are at an increased risk.
  • Radial keratoneuritis is pathognomonic.

 

Option C: Onchocerca volvulus

 

  • Onchocerca volvulus causes onchocerciasis, commonly seen in African countries.
  • Symptoms include sclerosing keratitis, uveitis, chorioretinitis, and optic neuritis.
  • Ultimately, it can lead to optic atrophy.

 

Option D: Chlamydia A to C

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis serovars A, B, Ba, and C are responsible for hyperendemic (blinding) trachoma.
  • The source of infection is infected conjunctival discharge.
  • If there is no secondary bacterial infection, symptoms include lacrimation, scanty mucoid discharge, and foreign body sensation.
  • Conjunctival congestion and follicles, papillary hyperplasia, Herbert follicles (seen in the limbal area), and progressive pannus are the characteristic features.
  • Serovars D to K cause neonatal and adult inclusion conjunctivitis.
  • Neonates present with conjunctival discharge, chemosis, and swollen lids.
  • Adult inclusion conjunctivitis is more commonly seen in sexually active adults and presents with foreign body sensation, mild photophobia, and mucopurulent discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi palsy, and loss of corneal sensation—are indicative of neurogenic involvement, which is characteristic of leprosy, caused by Mycobacterium leprae.

questions.text: In urea cycle disorders, which of the following can be used to reduce the levels of ammonia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phenylbutyrate

 

In urea cycle disorders ammonia cannot be converted to urea, but alternatively can be converted to glutamine and glycine. Ammonia scavengers phenylbutyrate and sodium benzoate react with glutamine and glycine and consequently remove excess of ammonia. Phenylglutamine and hippurate are excreted in urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutamate: While glutamate can bind ammonia to form glutamine, it does not directly reduce ammonia levels through excretion.

 

Option C. Isoleucine: An amino acid that does not have a role in reducing ammonia levels in urea cycle disorders.

 

Option D. L-carnitine: Involved in the transport of fatty acids into mitochondria for beta-oxidation, but it does not play a role in reducing ammonia levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phenylbutyrate is used in urea cycle disorders to reduce ammonia levels by converting ammonia into phenylacetylglutamine, which is then excreted in the urine.

questions.text: As a physician on a disaster preparedness committee in a region prone to natural disasters, you are discussing the appropriate sequence of actions following a disaster. Which of the following sequences correctly represents the appropriate steps in disaster management after the event has taken place? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Response – Rehabilitation – Reconstruction – Mitigation – Preparedness

 

The correct sequence after a disaster as per the general disaster management principles is:

 

  1. Response: Immediate actions taken to ensure safety, provide emergency services, and stabilize the situation. This involves –
    • Search, rescue and first aid
    • Field care
    • Triage
    • Tagging
    • Identification of dead
  2. Rehabilitation: Short-term recovery and normalization of operations to restore basic services and functions in the affected area.
  3. Reconstruction: Long-term rebuilding of infrastructure and restoration of a fully functional community.
  4. Mitigation: Efforts to reduce the risk and lessen the impact of future disasters.
  5. Preparedness: Planning and preparation to improve response activities for future disasters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disaster Cycle

choices.text: Iron deficiency anemia
B12 deficiency
Hereditary spherocytosis
Acute myeloid leukemia

questions.text: What is your diagnosis with respect to the findings shown in the peripheral smear given below? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B12 deficiency

 

The peripheral smear provided shows the presence of macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. These findings are characteristic of megaloblastic anemia, which is most commonly caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate.

 

  • Macro-ovalocytes are large, oval-shaped red blood cells that result from impaired DNA synthesis, which occurs in megaloblastic anemia.
  • Hypersegmented neutrophils are neutrophils with more than the normal number of nuclear lobes (usually more than five). This is a classic finding in vitamin B12 or folate deficiency.

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to impaired DNA synthesis, causing ineffective erythropoiesis and resulting in the release of abnormally large red blood cells (macro-ovalocytes) and hypersegmented neutrophils into the circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: This typically presents with microcytic hypochromic red blood cells, not macro-ovalocytes or hypersegmented neutrophils.

 

Option C. Hereditary spherocytosis: This condition is characterized by the presence of spherocytes (small, round, dense red blood cells) and not macro-ovalocytes or hypersegmented neutrophils.

 

Option D. Acute myeloid leukemia: AML is characterized by the presence of blasts in the peripheral blood smear, which are immature white blood cells, not macro-ovalocytes or hypersegmented neutrophils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils in a peripheral smear is indicative of B12 deficiency and megaloblastic anemia.

choices.text: Documentation of injuries and examination findings

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl, accompanied by her mother, is brought to a lady police sub-inspector, alleging a history of sexual violence that occurred two days ago. The next course of action for the registered medical practitioner would be?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Take a detailed history

 

The next course of action involves the registered medical practitioner gathering a comprehensive medical history.

 

The registered medical professional must conduct a comprehensive medical history review and obtain informed consent before proceeding with the examination. If the individual declines the examination, a well-documented informed refusal must be obtained, clearly explaining the potential consequences of their decision.

 

During the examination process, the medical practitioner should gather necessary specimens, preserve any relevant clothing, and meticulously document all injuries and findings. It is essential to provide free medical treatment and conduct pregnancy testing for all victims of sexual assault, as mandated by law under section 357-C of CrPc. Additionally, the police must be notified accordingly.

 

Other Options

 

Option B: Preserve clothing: Preserving clothing is essential for forensic evidence but should follow after taking a detailed history to ensure the context is understood and evidence is collected appropriately.

 

Option C: Take consent for genital examination: Taking consent for a genital examination is critical but must come after obtaining a detailed history to ensure the examination is conducted respectfully and with full understanding of the context.

 

Option D: Documentation of injuries and examination findings: Documentation of injuries and examination findings is vital for forensic and medical records but should be done after taking a detailed history and obtaining informed consent.

 

Educational Objective

 

In cases of alleged sexual violence, the initial and crucial step for the registered medical practitioner is to take a detailed history from the victim.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient undergoes a pacemaker replacement procedure at a tertiary care hospital. The surgeon successfully replaces the pacemaker and hands over the used device to the nursing staff for proper disposal as per biomedical waste management guidelines. According to the guidelines for biomedical waste management, in which colored bag should the used pacemaker be discarded? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Blue

 

  • According to biomedical waste management guidelines, used pacemakers, which are considered metal waste, should be disposed of in blue-colored containers or cardboard boxes marked with blue.
  • This ensures that the device is appropriately handled, disinfected, and sent for recycling or other safe disposal methods.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the most likely causative organism of ventilator-associated pneumonia among the following? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acinetobacter.

 

Acinetobacter species are particularly prevalent in hospital settings and are a common cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). These organisms are known for their ability to survive on surfaces for extended periods and their resistance to multiple antibiotics, making them a significant concern in intensive care units where patients are often intubated. Acinetobacter, along with Pseudomonas and Stenotrophomonas, is known for colonizing the respiratory tract of ventilated patients, leading to VAP, which typically occurs after 48 hours of mechanical ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clostridium: This genus, including species like Clostridium difficile, is more commonly associated with gastrointestinal infections, particularly antibiotic-associated diarrhea, rather than pneumonia.

 

Option B. Klebsiella: While Klebsiella pneumoniae can cause ventilator-associated pneumonia, it is generally less common than Acinetobacter in this specific infection context. Klebsiella tends to be more associated with community-acquired pneumonia and hospital-acquired infections outside of the ventilator context.

 

Option D. Haemophilus: Haemophilus influenzae can cause respiratory tract infections but is more commonly linked to community-acquired pneumonia and exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease rather than VAP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acinetobacter, pseudomonas, stenotrophomonas, Burkholderia cepacia are common organisms causing VAP. VAP occurs due to colonization by organisms in < 48 hours.

 

Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/Pneumonia/Chap 142

questions.text:
What is the antidote of cyanide poisoning? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

A. Amyl Nitrite
B. Sodium Nitrite
C. Sodium Thiosulphate
D. Benzyl Thiocyanate
E. Sodium Nitroprusside
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ABC

 

Cyanide poisoning inhibits cytochrome C oxidase, a key enzyme in the mitochondrial electron transport chain, leading to cellular hypoxia and lactic acidosis. The treatment for cyanide poisoning involves agents that either bind to cyanide, facilitating its excretion, or convert it into a less toxic form.

 

A. Amyl Nitrite and B. Sodium Nitrite: These compounds oxidize hemoglobin to methemoglobin, which has a higher affinity for cyanide than cytochrome C oxidase. This process frees cytochrome C oxidase and forms cyanmethemoglobin.

 

C. Sodium Thiosulphate: This compound acts directly by converting cyanmethemoglobin to thiocyanate, which is less toxic and is excreted in the urine. Additionally, it directly breaks the bond between cytochrome C oxidase and cyanide.

 

D. Benzyl Thiocyanate: This is not a recognized treatment for cyanide poisoning and does not have the properties needed to detoxify cyanide.

 

E. Sodium Nitroprusside: This compound, while containing cyanide groups, is not used as an antidote for cyanide poisoning. It is actually a source of cyanide and is used for different medical purposes, such as vasodilation in hypertensive emergencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The main antidotes for cyanide poisoning include amyl nitrite, sodium nitrite, and sodium thiosulphate. These agents work by either converting cyanide into a less toxic form or by forming methemoglobin which binds to cyanide, freeing cytochrome C oxidase.

choices.text: Start ART after 2-3 weeks
Opening pressure will be normal
Start amphotericin monotherapy
80% of patients will have positive radiological findings

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presented with headache and neck stiffness. Fundoscopy revealed papilledema. India ink staining of the CSF showed an encapsulated organism. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start ART after 2-3 weeks

 

The clinical presentation and findings suggest cryptococcosis, and the causative organism is Cryptococcus neoformans. In HIV patients with Cryptococcus infection, it is important to delay the initiation of antiretroviral therapy (ART) until 2-3 weeks after starting antifungal treatment. This delay is necessary to reduce the risk of immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS), which can worsen the symptoms due to a strong immune response against the dying organisms.

 

Cryptococcus neoformans typically causes cryptococcal meningitis in immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV/AIDS. Symptoms include headache, neck stiffness, altered mental status, and sometimes photophobia. Papilledema can indicate raised intracranial pressure, a common complication of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Opening pressure will be normal: Incorrect. Raised intracranial pressure is common in cryptococcal meningitis, and lumbar puncture often reveals elevated opening pressures.

 

Option C. Start amphotericin monotherapy: Incorrect. The recommended initial treatment is a combination of amphotericin B and flucytosine, not monotherapy, for better efficacy and to reduce resistance.

 

Option D. 80% of patients will have positive radiological findings: Incorrect. Imaging like MRI or CT scan is not always reliable in diagnosing cryptococcal meningitis and may only show abnormalities in about 21-27% of cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with HIV who develop cryptococcal meningitis, ART should be delayed for 2-3 weeks after starting antifungal treatment to reduce the risk of IRIS, which could exacerbate clinical symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following does not present with maculopapular rash? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zoster (shingles)

 

A maculopapular rash is not seen in zoster (shingles).

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

Herpes zoster:

 

  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  1. Painful zoster infections in adults
  2. Facial zoster at any age
  3. Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rubella: Presents with a maculopapular rash as shown in the image below, which consists of minute, discrete macules.

 

 

  • The rash appears within 24 hours of onset of prodromal symptoms.

 

Option C. Dengue (during febrile phase): Dengue fever can present with a maculopapular rash during its febrile phase.

 

Option D. Measles: Measles is characterized by fever and a maculopapular skin rash, which is accompanied by immune clearance of measles virus (MV)-infected cells

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zoster (shingles) does not present with a maculopapular rash but rather with a painful, vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution. In contrast, rubella, dengue during the febrile phase, and measles are classic causes of maculopapular rashes.
 

 

Ref- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no. 25.27-25.28
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106
Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

choices.text: Chronic Cocaine use
Subacute progression over 4 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT indicative of underlying serious pathology in headache? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic Cocaine use

 

While acute cocaine use can lead to serious complications such as intracranial hemorrhage, chronic cocaine use does not typically present as a headache warning sign for serious pathology unless associated with acute episodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age > 50: New onset headache in individuals over 50 years of age is a red flag and suggests the possibility of serious conditions such as giant cell arteritis or intracranial mass lesions.

 

Option B. Temporal tenderness: This is often a sign of temporal arteritis (giant cell arteritis), a serious condition that can lead to blindness if not treated promptly.

 

Option D. Subacute progression over 4 weeks: This indicates a progressive condition such as a brain tumor or increased intracranial pressure, which are serious pathologies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic cocaine use is not typically indicative of a serious underlying pathology in headache unless associated with acute episodes.

 

Headache Symptoms That Suggest a Serious Underlying Disorder

 

  • Sudden-onset headache
  • First severe headache
  • "Worst" headache ever
  • Vomiting that precedes headache
  • Subacute worsening over days or weeks
  • Pain induced by bending, lifting, coughing
  • Pain that disturbs sleep or presents immediately upon awakening
  • Known systemic illness
  • Onset after age 55
  • Fever or unexplained systemic signs
  • Abnormal neurologic examination
  • Pain associated with local tenderness, e.g., region of temporal artery

questions.text: A bashful young man who prefers social solitude appears emotionally frigid and lives alone. There is no history of delusions or hallucinations. The most likely explanation is? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schizoid personality disorder

 

Schizoid personality disorder is marked by detachment from social relationships and a restricted range of emotional expression. Individuals prefer solitude and appear emotionally cold.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paranoid personality disorder: It is characterized by excessive suspiciousness and distrust of others. They may be excessively sensitive and give excessive importance to themselves. The vignette described above does not mention suspiciousness, infact mentions there is no history of delusions. Hence the answer is not paranoid personality disorder.

 

Option C. Antisocial personality disorder: These patients disregard others' rights and frequently violates them. They frequently get involved in unlawful behaviours such as theft, conning etc. 

 

Option D. Emotionally unstable personality disorder: Otherwise known as Borderline personality disorder. They are almost always in the state of crisis. They have a history of unstable relationships and emotions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by detachment from social relationships and prefer solitary activities. They are emotionally cold and are indifferent to praise or criticism. There is also an absence of close relationships. It is classified as a Cluster A personality disorder.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 2152

questions.text: During your clinical rotation, you notice the different color-coded waste bins meticulously arranged by the nursing staff as per the hospital's waste management protocol. If you were to guide a new intern about the appropriate disposal of items, which item among the following would you instruct them to discard in the black bin? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Glove paper cover

 

  • The paper cover for gloves constitutes regular solid waste, which should be placed in the designated black bin.
  • All types of non-infectious general refuse, including food waste, paper waste, and mineral water bottles, ought to be deposited in the black bins.
  • Bedsheets and linens that are soiled and contaminated with blood or bodily fluids should be appropriately disposed of in the yellow bin.
  • Plastic materials that are recyclable, such as gloves and contaminated gloves, should be placed in the red bins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soiled linen bedsheet: Should be disposed of in the yellow bin for contaminated waste.

 

Option C. Gloves: Should be placed in the red bin for recyclable materials.

 

Option D. Contaminated gloves: Also go in the red bin for medical waste.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-infectious general refuse, such as glove paper covers, should be discarded in the black bin.

questions.text:
What are the objective tests used to assess hearing?

 

  1. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry)
  2. OAE (Otoacoustic emission)
  3. PTA (Pure tone audiometry)
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Objective hearing tests are those that do not require a response from the patient and are used to assess hearing ability or the integrity of parts of the hearing pathway.

 

1. BERA - Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential) is an objective test to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain

 

 

2. OAE is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a very sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal and analyzed by a computer.

 

4. Tympanometry is an objective test for compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system.

 

 

 

Other Option:

 

3. Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA): PTA requires the patient's active participation to indicate when a sound is heard. It tests the hearing threshold levels of an individual, enabling determination of the degree, type, and configuration of a hearing loss, thus classifying it as a subjective test.

 

Other examples of subjective tests include tuning fork tests and speech audiometry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objective tests such as BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic data without requiring any active response from the patient, thus suitable for use in patients who may not be able to respond reliably, such as young children or those with certain disabilities.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 25, 26, 29

questions.text: All of the following are derivatives of NCC except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinal pigment membrane

 

The retinal pigment membrane (or retinal pigment epithelium, RPE) develops from the ectoderm of the optic cup, which is an outgrowth of the developing brain, and not from neural crest cells. The neural retina and RPE both develop from the neuroectoderm of the optic vesicle, making them extensions of the central nervous system rather than neural crest derivatives.
 

Neural crest cells (NCCs)

Ciliary muscles

Melanocytes

Ciliary ganglion

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ciliary muscles: The ciliary muscles develop from neural crest cells that contribute to the development of structures in the eye.

 

Option C. Melanocytes: Melanocytes throughout the body, including those in the skin and iris, are derived from neural crest cells that migrate from the neural tube during embryonic development.

 

Option D. Ciliary ganglion: The ciliary ganglion, a parasympathetic ganglion associated with the eye, is derived from neural crest cells. Neural crest cells give rise to all parasympathetic ganglia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neural crest cells give rise to diverse structures including melanocytes, parasympathetic ganglia (including ciliary ganglion), and components of the eye (like ciliary muscles), but the retinal pigment epithelium develops from the optic cup neuroectoderm.

questions.text: A patient with lytic lesions on the skull is suspected of a diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Which of the following is a characteristic finding on electron microscopy? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Birbeck granules

 

The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is a characteristic finding of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) on electron microscopy.

 

Birbeck granules have a dilated terminal end producing a tennis racket-like appearance. It contains the protein langerin (CD207). It is seen on electron microscopy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histiocytes: While LCH involves histiocytic cells (specifically Langerhans cells), the mere presence of histiocytes is not specific to LCH. Many other conditions can also involve histiocytes, so this option is too general.

 

Option C. Eosinophils: Eosinophils are often present in LCH lesions, contributing to the inflammatory response, but they are not a characteristic finding on electron microscopy and are not specific to LCH.

 

Option D. Giant cells: Giant cells may be seen in various granulomatous conditions but are not a characteristic finding specific to LCH on electron microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Birbeck granules on electron microscopy is a characteristic finding in Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH), confirming the diagnosis of this condition.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition Pg 1168

questions.text: Cytochrome C oxidase is inhibited by all EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methane

 

  • Methane does not inhibit cytochrome C oxidase.
  • Cytochrome C oxidase is primarily inhibited by substances that interfere with the electron transport chain, such as cyanide and carbon monoxide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. H2S (Hydrogen Sulfide):

  • H2S can inhibit cytochrome C oxidase.
  • It is a known inhibitor of this enzyme and can disrupt mitochondrial respiration.

 

Option C. CO (Carbon Monoxide):

  • CO is a potent inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase.
  • It binds to the same heme groups in the enzyme's active site as oxygen, preventing oxygen from binding and disrupting electron transport.

 

Option D. Cyanide:

  • Cyanide is a strong inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase.
  • It binds to the iron in the enzyme's heme groups, blocking the transfer of electrons in the electron transport chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CN, CO and H2S are inhibitors of Cytochrome c Oxidase (Complex IV of ETC). They inhibit by non-competitive inhibition and this type of inhibition is mostly irreversible. For a complete list of ETC inhibitors refer to table below:

 

Inhibitor of ETC complexes

 

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 123

questions.text: As the in-charge epidemiologist of an urban CHC, you've been reviewing the weekly infectious disease reports. In a particular community under your jurisdiction, you observe that dengue case counts typically range from 40 to 50 cases every week. During your current weekly review, you note there are 48 reported cases of dengue. Based on this data and your understanding of epidemiological terminology, how would you classify this week's situation with respect to dengue? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Endemic 

 

  • The given scenario is an example of an endemic disease.

 

Endemic

 

  • Endemic: Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent in a defined geographical area. It is the ‘usual or expected frequency’ of a disease in a population
  • Types of Endemic:
    • Hyper-endemic: Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent at high incidence/prevalence AND affects all age groups equally
    • Holo-endemic: A high level of infection beginning early in life AND affecting most of the children population

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidemic: Incorrect because an epidemic refers to an increase in the number of cases of a disease beyond what is normally expected in that population in that area. The current case count does not exceed the usual range.

 

Option C. Sporadic: Incorrect because sporadic refers to a disease that occurs infrequently and irregularly; here, the cases are neither infrequent nor irregular.

 

Option D. Outbreak: Similar to an epidemic, an outbreak implies a greater-than-anticipated increase in the number of cases within a small, localized area over a short period. Again, since the case count is within normal expectations, this term does not apply.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endemic: Is the ‘usual or expected frequency’ of a disease in a population

choices.text: Calcium channel blocker

questions.text: For the diagnosis of resistant hypertension, the patient should have uncontrolled hypertension despite taking three antihypertensive drugs. This should include at least one? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diuretic

 

Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure that remains above the target levels despite the use of three antihypertensive agents of different classes, one of which should be a diuretic. This is because diuretics, typically thiazide diuretics, help to reduce blood volume and are effective in lowering blood pressure. Including a diuretic ensures optimal blood pressure control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium channel blockers: Calcium channel blockers are used but are not specifically required for the diagnosis of resistant hypertension.

 

Option B. Beta blockers: Beta blockers are also commonly used but not specifically required for the definition.

 

Option C. Alpha blockers: Alpha blockers may be used as part of the treatment regimen but are not specifically required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnostic criteria for resistant hypertension include having blood pressure above target despite taking three drugs, one of which must be a diuretic, OR having controlled blood pressure with four or more drugs. Typically, a thiazide diuretic is used in the setting of hypertension.

choices.text: 1, 3 and 4
1, 2 and 4
2, 3 and 4

questions.text:
Which of the following method of disinfection and sterilization can also kill spores? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Glutaraldehyde
  2. Ethylene oxide
  3. Pasteurization
  4. Ortho-phthalaldehyde
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4

 

Glutaraldehyde, Ethylene oxide, and Ortho-phthalaldehyde are effective methods of disinfection and sterilization that can kill spores.

 

1. Glutaraldehyde: This chemical is a broad-spectrum microbicidal and sporicidal agent. It is known for its compatibility with a variety of medical instruments. However, it requires activation and produces irritant fumes, which are notable disadvantages. Despite these drawbacks, glutaraldehyde is commonly recommended for the disinfection of fibroscopes and respiratory equipment due to its efficacy against spores and other microorganisms.

 

2. ETO (Ethylene oxide) inactivates all microorganisms although bacterial spores (especially B. atrophaeus) are more resistant than other microorganisms. For this reason B. atrophaeus is the recommended biological indicator. ETO is used in healthcare facilities to sterilize critical items (and sometimes semicritical items) that are moisture or heat sensitive and cannot be sterilized by steam sterilization like syringes, needles, catheters, and gloves. Bacillus atrophaeus and Bacillus subtilis are used as sterilization control.

 

4. Ortho-phthalaldehyde: Similar to glutaraldehyde, ortho-phthalaldehyde is a broad-spectrum microbicidal and sporicidal agent. It does not require activation and does not produce irritating fumes, which are significant advantages. However, it is costly and can stain medical equipment. It is often used as an alternative to glutaraldehyde for disinfecting scopes.

 

Other Options

 

3. Pasteurization or pasteurization is a process of food preservation in which packaged and non-packaged foods (such as milk and fruit juices) are treated with mild heat, usually to less than 100 °C (212 °F), to eliminate pathogens and extend shelf life. It has no sporicidal activity and kills non-spore-forming bacteria like Mycobacteria, Brucella, and Salmonella. There are two methods-

 

  1. Holder method -  milk is heated at either 63°C for 30 minutes. Coxiella burnetii is relatively heat resistant and may survive the holder method.
  2. Flash method - milk is heated at 72°C for 15-20 seconds followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman landed up in AIIMS emergency after a road traffic accident with GCS of 3. She was intubated and sent for NCCT which was found to be normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Diffuse axonal injury

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of the patient who had an RTA presents with an abnormal clinical manifestation and no imaging abnormality suggests diffuse axonal injury.

 

Initial investigation for DAI→ NCCT: Normal or tiny microbleeds

 

IOC for DAI → MRI

 

Sequence of MRI best: SWI/ Gradient MR: Shows blooming suggestive of axonal shearing

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Post-concussion syndrome: This generally follows a mild traumatic brain injury, not severe cases presenting with a GCS of 3 and typically involves symptoms like headaches, dizziness, and cognitive difficulties developing after the injury.

 

Option C. Extradural hemorrhage: This condition would usually present with a focal mass effect on an NCCT, which was not noted in this case.

 

Option D. Herniation of brain: Brain herniation typically shows significant structural displacement on NCCT, which was reported as normal in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diffuse axonal injury is a significant concern in patients with severe trauma and low GCS, especially when initial NCCT scans do not reveal significant abnormalities. MRI, particularly with SWI or gradient MR sequences, is crucial for proper diagnosis due to its sensitivity to microbleeds and axonal injuries.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the surgeon with a recurrent inguinal hernia. The surgeon decides to perform a hernioplasty, and the patient inquiries about the most appropriate type of mesh to be used. The surgeon wants to ensure that the patient is aware of the various types of meshes that can be used in hernioplasty. Which of the following is the most appropriate mesh for use in hernioplasty? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lightweight mesh with large pores

 

Lightweight meshes with large pores are considered the most appropriate choice for hernioplasty. They provide adequate support to repair the hernia while allowing for better tissue integration and reduced inflammation. This type of mesh is associated with lower postoperative pain and discomfort.

 

Heavyweight mesh:

 

  • Heavyweight meshes are typically not recommended for hernioplasty because they can lead to increased inflammation, tissue response, and a higher risk of complications. They may cause stiffness and discomfort in the area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most appropriate mesh to use in hernioplasty is a lightweight mesh with large pores.
  • Lightweight meshes induce a less-pronounced foreign body reaction and decreased inflammatory response, leading to better tissue incorporation, increased prosthesis compliance, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.
  • Meshes with large pores allow for increased soft tissue ingrowth and exhibit less inflammatory infiltrate, connective tissue, and scar bridging. This results in less adhesion, better tissue incorporation, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.
  • “Meshes with thinner strands and larger spaces (pores) between them are preferred because they have better tissue integration, less contracture, less foreign body reaction, more flexibility and improved comfort.” Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1063.
  • Meshes used in hernioplasty can be synthetic or biological, with synthetic meshes made from Polypropylene, Polyester, or PTFE.

questions.text: Bio-film confer resistance to antibiotics by all except? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adherence

 

Adherence is a mechanism of bacteria to attach to host cell for penetration. It is not a mechanism of resistance.

 

Mechanisms of biofilm-mediated resistance to antibiotics:

 

  • Mechanical barrier: The lipopolysaccharide biofilms prevent entry of water-soluble drugs.
  • Efflux pumps: These pumps on the biofilms actively excrete drug out.
  • Slow metabolism: Decreased oxygen and nutrients passage through the biofilms slows down the metabolism of bacteria.
  • Anaerobic pathway: Because of the above reason bacteria follow anaerobic metabolism.
  • Persisters: Some bacteria undergo phenotypic modification into dormant, spore-like structure and survive antibiotic insult. These are called as persisters which are activated later.
  • Enzymatic inactivation of drugs by biofilms
  • Genetic adaptation to antibiotic insults
  • Quorum sensing: It is cell to cell signaling among the bacteria to coordinate among themselves for contribution in biofilm synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mechanical barrier: Correct. Biofilms provide a physical barrier that prevents the entry of antibiotics.

 

Option B. Increased excretion of antibiotics: Correct. Efflux pumps in biofilms actively expel antibiotics, reducing their intracellular concentration.

 

Option C. Slow metabolism: Correct. The slow metabolic rate within biofilms makes bacteria less susceptible to antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biofilms confer resistance to antibiotics through mechanisms such as mechanical barriers, efflux pumps, slow metabolism, and the presence of persisters. Adherence, while important for colonization, does not contribute directly to antibiotic resistance within biofilms.

questions.text: A female from Himachal Pradesh presented with H/O thorn prick, a year back has a verrucous lesion in the skin with the following microscopic findings. Identify the agent? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromoblastomycosis

 

The given clinical history and histopathological image are suggestive of Chromoblastomycosis

 

Chromoblastomycosis (chromomycosis) is a subcutaneous mycotic infection that is usually caused by traumatic inoculation.

 

Over months to years, the primary lesion becomes verrucous and wart-like with extension along the draining lymphatics.

 

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells (medlar/copper penny bodies)

 

The following are the various dematiaceous species of fungi

 

  • Phialophora verrucosa
  • Fonsecaea pedrosoi
  • Fonsecaea compacta
  • Rhinocladiella aquaspersa
  • Cladophialophora carrionii

 

Treatment: Surgical excision with wide margins is the treatment of choice for small lesions. Chemotherapy with flucytosine or itraconazole may be efficacious for larger lesions. The application of local heat is also beneficial.

 

MEDLAR/ SCLEROTIC BODIES

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomycosis: Blastomycosis is a systemic fungal infection caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. It does not typically present with the sclerotic bodies seen in Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option B. Pheohyphomycosis: Pheohyphomycosis is a broad term for infections caused by dematiaceous fungi but lacks the characteristic sclerotic bodies seen in Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis: Sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii, typically presents with lymphocutaneous lesions but does not show the sclerotic bodies characteristic of Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromoblastomycosis is identified by its characteristic histopathological features, including granulomatous lesions with dark sclerotic bodies (Medlar or copper penny bodies), and is caused by various dematiaceous fungi. The clinical history of a thorn prick and the verrucous lesion further support this diagnosis.

choices.text: A-1, B-3, C-4, D-2
A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3
A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2
A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

questions.text: Match the following bacteria with the drug of choice used for each? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3

 

  1. Vancomycin is Drug of Choice for Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) – It acts by inhibiting the cell wall synthesis and is a bactericidal drug.
  2. Metronidazole drug of choice against anaerobic infections caused by Bacteroides.
  3. Meropenem is used in infections caused by Klebsiella. Klebsiella is known to produce ESBL (Extended Spectrum Beta Lactamases). Carbapenems are not hydrolyzed by ESBL. Therefore, carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem, ertapenem are indicated in the treatment of infections caused by ESBL producing bacteria.
  4. Penicillin like amoxicillin, ampicillin can be used in H. influenzae infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Metronidazole is the drug of choice for anaerobic infections caused by Bacteroides.
  • Vancomycin is the drug of choice for infections caused by MRSA.
  • Penicillins like amoxicillin and ampicillin are used for Haemophilus influenzae infections.
  • Meropenem is used for infections caused by Klebsiella, particularly ESBL-producing strains.

questions.text: Which toxin acts via the mechanism depicted in the image below? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Botulinum

 

The image given above depicts the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin.

 

Clostridium botulinum is non-invasive. Its pathogenesis is due to the production of powerful neurotoxin ‘botulinum toxin’ (BoNT). It produces flaccid paralysis. There are 7 serological types of botulinum neurotoxin labeled as types A, B, C [C1 C2], D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is caused mainly by types A, B, E and F (rarely).

 

After entry (either ingested, inhaled, or produced in a wound), botulinum toxin is transported via the blood to peripheral cholinergic nerve terminals. The most common nerve terminal sites are neuromuscular junctions, postganglionic parasympathetic nerve endings, and peripheral ganglia. It does not affect the CNS.

 

Botulinum toxin causes proteolysis of snare proteins that are required for the excocytosis of acetylcholine vesicles, thereby preventing the release of acetylcholine (Ach) at the peripheral nerve endings, including neuromuscular junctions (presynaptic inhibition). This results in a lack of stimulus to the muscle fibers, irreversible relaxation of the muscles to presynaptic inhibition of neuronal, and flaccid paralysis.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Tetanus: Tetanus toxin (produced by Clostridium tetani) acts by inhibiting neurotransmitter release in the central nervous system by cleaving synaptobrevin, another SNARE protein, but it causes spastic paralysis rather than flaccid paralysis.

 

Option C. Diphtheria: Diphtheria toxin (produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae) inhibits protein synthesis in host cells by ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor-2 (EF-2), which is a completely different mechanism from that of botulinum toxin.

 

Option D. Pertussis: Pertussis toxin (produced by Bordetella pertussis) modifies the signaling of G-protein coupled receptors by ADP-ribosylating the Gi protein, thereby affecting cellular communication but not directly impacting acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junctions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Botulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by preventing the release of acetylcholine at peripheral nerve endings through the proteolysis of SNARE proteins necessary for acetylcholine vesicle exocytosis.

questions.text: An adolescent girl complains of dropping objects from hands precipitated during morning hours and exams. There is no history of loss of consciousness. One of her cousins has been diagnosed with epilepsy. EEG was suggestive of epileptic spikes. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy


The clinical presentation described is consistent with Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME). JME is characterized by myoclonic jerks, which are sudden, brief, involuntary muscle contractions typically involving both arms. These jerks are most frequent in the morning, often leading to the dropping of objects, as described in this case. The patient maintains consciousness during these episodes, which is typical for JME.

 

Factors supporting the diagnosis:

 

  • Myoclonic jerks: The hallmark seizure type in JME, often occurring shortly after waking up in the morning.
  • Maintained consciousness: The patient remains aware during the myoclonic jerks.
  • Triggers: Seizures can be triggered by stimuli such as sleep deprivation, stress, and photic stimulation (e.g., flashing lights).
  • Genetics: A mutation in the GABRA1 gene is associated with JME.
  • Treatment: Sodium valproate is the drug of choice.
  • Prognosis: Generally good with appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atypical absence: Absence seizures are characterized by brief lapses in consciousness without motor symptoms like dropping objects. Atypical absences last longer than typical ones and have slower onset and resolution.

 

Option C. Choreo-athetoid epilepsy: This condition involves involuntary irregular movements of the face, head, trunk, and extremities, which does not align with the symptoms described in this case.

 

Option D. Centrotemporal spikes: Benign Epilepsy with Centrotemporal Spikes (BECTS), also known as Rolandic epilepsy, involves brief stereotypical partial seizures, typically with facial and oropharyngeal involvement, not consistent with the symptomatology in this case.

 

Educational Objective:


Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME) is characterized by myoclonic jerks, typically occurring in the morning, with preserved consciousness and a good response to sodium valproate.

questions.text: You are an intern and want to determine the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient. How much amount of transient loss/insensible loss per day would you account for in your calculations? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 500-600 ml

 

Some of the water losses cannot be precisely regulated. For example, there is a continuous loss of water by evaporation from the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin, which together account for about 500-600 ml/day of water loss under normal conditions. This is termed insensible water loss because we are not consciously aware of it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When calculating the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient, it is essential to account for approximately 500-600 ml/day of insensible water loss due to evaporation from the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin.

choices.text: Drug 1 represents agonist and drug 2 represents inverse agonist﻿﻿﻿
Drug 3 represents agonist and drug 4 represents inverse agonist
﻿﻿﻿Drug 1 represents agonist and drug 4 represents inverse agonist
﻿﻿﻿Drug 2 represents partial agonist and drug 3 represents inverse agonist

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct regarding the given graph?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Drug 1 represents agonist and drug 4 represents inverse agonist

 

Drug 1 = Full agonist, showing the maximal effect, having an intrinsic efficacy of +1

 

E.g., Salbutamol is a β2 receptor agonist

 

Drug 2 = Partial agonist, produces submaximal effect and has an intrinsic efficacy in the range of 0 to +1. E.g., Buprenorphine at the opioid receptors.

 

Drug 3 = Antagonist, having no effect of its own at the receptor, that is an intrinsic efficacy of 0.

 

E.g., Naltrexone and Naloxone at the opioid receptors.

 

Drug 4 = Inverse agonist, produces opposite effect and has a negative intrinsic efficacy.

 

E.g., Beta-Carboline is an inverse agonist at benzodiazepine site of GABA-A receptor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drug 1: Shows the highest level of response, indicating it is a full agonist.

 

Drug 2: Shows a submaximal response, indicating it is a partial agonist.

 

Drug 3: Shows no change in response, indicating it is an antagonist.

 

Drug 4: Shows a negative response, indicating it is an inverse agonist.

questions.text: Which of the following infection presents with mucus in stools and abdominal pain? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Entamoeba

 

Stools with mucus and abdominal pain are seen in infection due to Entamoeba.

 

Clinical features of intestinal amebiasis:

 

  • Dysentery accompanied by lower abdominal discomfort and flatulence. Stools usually have blood and mucus.
  • Chronic amebiasis presents with low-grade symptoms such as occasional diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue.
  • A granulomatous lesion called an ameboma may form in the cecal or rectosigmoid areas of the colon which can resemble an adenocarcinoma of the colon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Giardia: Is often asymptomatic, but in some cases can lead to fat malabsorption, dull epigastric pain, and flatulence. BUT does not release mucus in stool.

 

Option C. Campylobacter: Presents with fever, pain and watery diarrhea. Stool contains leucocytes and blood.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcal food poisoning is toxin-mediated and presents with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entamoeba histolytica infection presents with dysentery, characterized by stools containing mucus and blood, along with abdominal pain.

questions.text: Preferred drug for the treatment of a 48-year-old man with uncomplicated grade 2 hypertension without any associated co-morbidity is (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chlorthalidone

 

  • Chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic that is highly effective in lowering blood pressure and is often recommended as the preferred first-line treatment for uncomplicated grade 2 hypertension. It has a longer duration of action compared to other thiazides, such as hydrochlorothiazide, making it particularly effective in managing hypertension over a 24-hour period.
  • According to ACC Guidelines and JNC 8 Guidelines, the DOC for hypertension is Thiazides (preferred diuretic).
  • Apart from thiazides, the other first line drugs for hypertension are-
  • ACE Inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers
  • Calcium channel blockers

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Triamterene: This is a potassium-sparing diuretic. It is primarily used in combination with other diuretics to prevent hypokalemia but is not recommended as a first-line treatment for hypertension.

 

Option C. Spironolactone: Another potassium-sparing diuretic, primarily used in conditions such as heart failure, hyperaldosteronism, and resistant hypertension, not as a first-line treatment for uncomplicated hypertension.

 

Option D. Furosemide: This is a loop diuretic, which is typically used in conditions such as congestive heart failure, renal insufficiency, and edema. It is not recommended as a first-line treatment for uncomplicated hypertension due to its short duration of action and the potential for significant electrolyte disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the treatment of uncomplicated grade 2 hypertension without any associated comorbidities, thiazide diuretics, particularly chlorthalidone, are the preferred first-line agents according to ACC and JNC 8 guidelines.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/615

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with 15 days of fever and altered sensorium for 1 day. A rapid diagnostic test was done, and Plasmodium falciparum was diagnosed. Which of the following is not a complication? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial pH >7.2

 

An arterial pH >7.2, however, is not considered a complication of severe malaria. In fact, severe acidosis is defined by an arterial pH of less than 7.25, and it is a sign of severe malaria. Therefore, an arterial pH >7.2 does not indicate severe malaria.

 

Other Options:

 

Plasmodium falciparum malaria is a severe form of malaria that can lead to numerous complications. The World Health Organization (WHO) defines several criteria for severe malaria, many of which are seen in complicated cases of Plasmodium falciparum infection.

 

Option A. Blood glucose <40 mg/dL: Severe hypoglycemia is a known complication of severe malaria, particularly in patients treated with quinine.

 

Option C. Serum creatinine - 5.2: This indicates severe renal impairment. Serum creatinine levels above 3 mg/dL or reduced urine output despite rehydration are markers of severe malaria.

 

Option D. Unarousable coma: Cerebral malaria, which includes unarousable coma or seizures, is one of the most severe complications of Plasmodium falciparum infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic criteria for identifying complicated falciparum malaria, based on clinical and laboratory findings:

 

  1. Arterial pH: An arterial pH of less than 7.25 is indicative of complicated falciparum malaria.
  2. Bicarbonate Levels: A bicarbonate level of less than 15 is also a sign of complicated falciparum malaria.
  3. Base Deficit: A base deficit of more than 8 is another indicator of severe disease.
  4. Hemoglobin: A hemoglobin level of less than 5, or the presence of hemoglobinuria, are significant markers of severity.
  5. Venous Lactate: A venous lactate level of more than 5 further confirms the complexity and severity of the malaria infection.
  6. Blood Glucose: A blood glucose level less than 40 mg/dL is a critical indicator of complicated falciparum malaria.
  7. Creatinine Levels: A creatinine level exceeding 3 mg/dL points to significant renal impairment associated with severe malaria.
  8. Urine Output: A urine output of less than 400 mL per day, despite adequate rehydration with IV fluids, also signifies complicated falciparum malaria.

questions.text: Identify the given bone marrow biopsy instrument. (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Klima needle

 

The instrument shown is a Klima needle, which is used for bone marrow aspiration and biopsy.

 

  • Klima and Salah’s needles are both reusable bone marrow aspiration and biopsy needles made of stainless steel.
  • The Klima needle is distinguished by having a guard that screws along the length of the needle, but it does not have a side screw.
  • Salah’s needle also has a guard, but it is situated 2 cm from the tip and has a side screw for added stability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salah's needle:


While similar to the Klima needle, Salah’s needle has a distinct side screw and guard located closer to the tip, which helps differentiate it from the Klima needle.

 

 

Option C. Jamshidi needle:


The Jamshidi needle has a tapered end, which helps reduce crush artifacts when obtaining bone marrow samples. It is often used for both diagnostic biopsy and aspiration.

 

 

Option D. Islam needle:


The Islam needle has a core securing device at the tip to hold the core of bone during the biopsy procedure.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Klima needle is used for bone marrow biopsy and is characterized by its guard without a side screw. It is crucial to differentiate between biopsy needles like Klima, Salah, Jamshidi, and Islam based on their structural features and specific use in medical procedures.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the use of morphine? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Acute myocardial infarction

 

Explanation:

 

Acute myocardial infarction: Morphine is often used in the setting of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) to relieve pain and anxiety. It also has the beneficial effect of reducing preload and afterload on the heart, which can decrease myocardial oxygen demand. This makes it beneficial in the management of AMI. It's not a contraindication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchial asthma: Morphine can induce histamine release, which may lead to bronchospasm. In patients with bronchial asthma, this bronchospasm can exacerbate respiratory difficulties, making morphine potentially dangerous for these patients.

 

Option B. Renal failure: Morphine is metabolized in the liver and its metabolites, especially morphine-6-glucuronide, are excreted by the kidneys. In the case of renal failure, these active metabolites can accumulate, leading to prolonged and potentially toxic effects.

 

Option C. Emphysema: Morphine has a depressive effect on the respiratory center in the brain, leading to respiratory depression. In patients with emphysema, a condition already characterized by compromised respiratory function, morphine can exacerbate respiratory difficulties and decrease the drive to breathe.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Morphine is beneficial and not contraindicated in the management of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) as it helps to relieve pain, reduce anxiety, and decrease myocardial oxygen demand.

questions.text: As a researcher designing a clinical study, you are exploring methods to eliminate confounding variables, which can lead to spurious associations between the independent and dependent variables. Which of the following methods is NOT primarily used to eliminate confounders? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Blinding

 

  • This method is used primarily to prevent bias in the conduct and interpretation of clinical research.
  • Blinding can be of participants, investigators, or those assessing outcomes, to ensure that the behaviors and evaluations are not influenced by knowledge of which treatment or intervention participants receive.
  • While blinding reduces bias, it does not specifically address the issue of confounding variables.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Randomization: By randomly assigning participants to different groups in a study, randomization aims to evenly distribute confounding variables across all groups, thus reducing their potential impact on the outcome. This helps ensure that any differences observed between groups can more reliably be attributed to the intervention itself rather than to external variables.

 

Option C. Restriction: This involves limiting the participants in a study to certain criteria, effectively isolating specific characteristics and reducing variation that could lead to confounding. For example, a study may restrict participants to a certain age range, gender, or health status to control for these variables.

 

Option D. Matching: Matching involves pairing participants in the treatment group with similar participants in the control group based on certain characteristics (e.g., age, sex, baseline health status). This technique helps to ensure that the treatment and control groups are comparable on these characteristics, thereby controlling for confounding variables related to them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blinding is used to remove Bias.

 

Confounding can be removed by:

 

  1. Matching (MC used /simplest)
  2. Randomisation (2nd Best Method)
  3. Restriction
  4. Stratification
  5. Statistical Modelling / Multivariate analysis (MVA)
  6. Stratified Randomization (Overall Best Method)

questions.text: Following instrument is used to measure: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proptosis

 

The image shows a Hertel exophthalmometer, which is specifically designed to measure proptosis—the forward displacement of the eye. 

 

This instrument directly measures how much the eyeball protrudes forward from the eye socket. It is essential in diagnosing conditions like thyroid eye disease where proptosis is a common feature.

 

  • Design and Use: It consists of a ruler and two lateral mirrors or prisms that align with the lateral orbital rim, allowing for accurate measurement of the anterior position of the cornea relative to the lateral orbital wall.
    1. Bilateral Assessment: The Hertel exophthalmometer can measure the protrusion of both eyes simultaneously, allowing for comparison between the two. This is vital for identifying asymmetrical proptosis, which can be an indicator of more serious unilateral orbital disease.
    2. Quantitative Data: It provides quantitative data that can help in monitoring the progression or resolution of orbital diseases over time. This is particularly useful in tracking the effectiveness of treatment for conditions that cause proptosis.
    3. Simple and Non-invasive: The device is straightforward to use and non-invasive, making it a patient-friendly tool for regular follow-up assessments in clinical settings.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Hertel exophthalmometer is a specialized tool for assessing the extent of proptosis in conditions affecting the orbit and surrounding tissues, helping guide further diagnostic and therapeutic steps for conditions like thyroid eye disease.

questions.text: Identify the following image. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Blister due to antemortem burns

 

The antemortem blister presents itself as an elevated dome, containing serous fluid enriched with proteins and chlorides. The surrounding base exhibits reddening and swollen papillae. In the case of antemortem burns, the adjacent skin displays heightened enzyme activity, particularly for sulfhydryl groups in all skin layers. This reaction is accompanied by increased levels of ATP, esterase’s, aminopeptidases, acid, and alkaline phosphatase. These vital reactions indicate notable cellular exudation and reactive tissue changes, which are distinctive features of antemortem burns.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blister due to barbiturate poisoning: Barbiturate poisoning typically causes CNS depression, respiratory issues, and cardiovascular problems, not specific blister formation like burns.

 

Option C. Edema due to chemical burn: Chemical burns might cause edema, but the specific blister shown in the image is more characteristic of thermal burns.

 

Option D. Pemphigus vulgaris: Pemphigus vulgaris presents with flaccid blisters and erosions rather than the tense blister shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antemortem burn blisters are characterized by elevated domes filled with serous fluid, reddened surrounding base, and high enzyme activity, indicating significant cellular and tissue reactions distinct from other types of blisters or burns.

questions.text: Match the following Amino acid products: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-3, B-1, C-2, D-4

 

  • Tyrosine (A) → Norepinephrine (3): Tyrosine is a precursor for catecholamines, including dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine. It's also used for melanin and thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • Tryptophan (B) → melatonin (1): Tryptophan is metabolized to serotonin, which is then converted to melatonin. Tryptophan is also a precursor for niacin (vitamin B3).
  • Glycine (C) → Glutathione (2): Glycine is one of the three amino acids that make up glutathione (along with glutamate and cysteine). Glycine is also used in heme synthesis, creatine synthesis, and bile acid conjugation.
  • Histidine (D) → Histamine (4): Histidine undergoes decarboxylation (removal of the carboxyl group) to form histamine, which is an important inflammatory mediator and neurotransmitter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amino Acid Conversions

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits a clinic in Mumbai for a consultation about family planning. She discusses various options and services with her healthcare provider. During the conversation, she asks about additional health screenings included in family planning services. Which of the following screenings is NOT typically included as part of family planning services in India? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Screening for HIV infection

 

  • Family planning services aim to support individuals and couples in managing their reproductive health, but not all health screenings are integrated into these services:
  • Screening for HIV infection: This screening, while crucial for overall health and particularly important in prenatal care to prevent mother-to-child transmission, is generally conducted as part of broader sexual health services rather than within the narrower scope of family planning services.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Screening for cervical cancer: This is typically included because it directly relates to reproductive health and can impact a woman’s long-term health and fertility.

 

Option B. Providing services for unmarried mothers: This includes counseling and support, reflecting a comprehensive approach to reproductive health care that supports all individuals, regardless of marital status.

 

Option D. Providing adoption services: Part of family planning services that helps individuals and couples prepare for parenthood, including the option of adoption, aligning with the broad goals of family planning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Family planning is not synonymous with birth control only. A WHO Expert Committee (1970) recommends that family planning includes in its’ purview:

 

  • Proper spacing and limitation of birth
  • Advice on sterility
  • Education for parenthood
  • Sex education
  • Screening for pathological conditions related to the reproductive system (e.g., cervical cancer)
  • Genetic counselling
  • Premarital consultation and examination
  • Pregnancy tests
  • Marriage counselling
  • Preparation of couples for the first child
  • Providing services to unmarried mothers
  • Teaching home economics and nutrition
  • Providing adoption services

choices.text: Ewing's sarcoma

questions.text: All are small round blue cell tumors except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemangioblastoma

 

Hemangioblastoma is not a small round blue cell tumor.

 

Many childhood tumors have been collectively referred to as small round blue cell tumors due to their primitive histologic appearance.

 

The differential diagnosis of such tumors includes neuroblastoma, Wilms tumor, lymphoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor, medulloblastoma and retinoblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing's sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is a classic example of a small round blue cell tumor. It is a highly malignant tumor that primarily affects bone and soft tissues, particularly in children and young adults.

 

Option C. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a small round blue cell tumor of the eye, commonly seen in children. It is characterized by the presence of small, undifferentiated cells with hyperchromatic nuclei.

 

Option D. Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma is another example of a small round blue cell tumor. It arises from neural crest cells and is most commonly found in the adrenal glands or along the sympathetic chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemangioblastoma is not classified as a small round blue cell tumor, unlike Ewing's sarcoma, retinoblastoma, and neuroblastoma.

 

Ref: Robbins and cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 882

questions.text: Match the surgery with related nerve injuries: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

 

The following are the associations between the type of surgery and the nerve most commonly at risk of injury:

 

A. Breast surgery - Long Thoracic Nerve: The Long Thoracic Nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which anchors the scapula to the chest wall. Injury to this nerve during breast surgery, especially radical mastectomies where axillary lymph nodes are removed, can lead to a condition called "winged scapula," where the medial border of the scapula protrudes outwards.

 

B. Thyroid surgery - External Laryngeal nerve: The External Laryngeal nerve is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (itself a branch of the vagus nerve). It supplies the cricothyroid muscle, which plays a role in tensioning the vocal cords. Injury during thyroid surgery can lead to voice changes, particularly affecting the pitch.

 

C. Submandibular excision - Hypoglossal nerve: The Hypoglossal nerve is the twelfth cranial nerve and supplies the muscles of the tongue. Injury to this nerve during excision of the submandibular gland can lead to tongue deviation towards the side of the injury due to the unopposed action of the tongue muscles on the unaffected side.

 

D. Thymectomy - Vagus nerve: The Vagus nerve, or the tenth cranial nerve, has a wide range of functions including supplying parasympathetic fibers to many organs in the thorax and abdomen. Injury during thymectomy, a surgical procedure to can have multiple effects, including voice changes due to its role in innervating the larynx. However, it's worth noting that the phrenic nerve, which innervates the diaphragm, is also at risk during a thymectomy.

 

In summary, during surgical procedures, it's imperative to be aware of the nearby nerves and their courses to prevent unintended nerve injury, as this can lead to significant postoperative complications

questions.text: Features of MEN2B are all except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parathyroid hyperplasia

 

MEN2B syndrome is characterized by a distinct set of clinical features known as the "4 M's":

 

  1. Marfanoid body habitus
  2. Mucosal neuromas
  3. Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC)
  4. Megacolon (Hirschsprung disease)

 

Additionally, pheochromocytoma is also a feature of MEN2B. The syndrome is caused by mutations in the RET proto-oncogene located on chromosome 10.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parathyroid hyperplasia is NOT a component of MEN2B syndrome, while the characteristic features include medullary thyroid carcinoma, mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and megacolon (the 4 M's).

choices.text: Middle meningeal artery - Anterior cranial fossa
Accessory meningeal branch of maxillary artery - Middle cranial fossa
Meningeal branch of internal carotid artery - Posterior cranial fossa
Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoid artery - Anterior cranial fossa

questions.text: Which of the following arteries does not supply the corresponding region of the dura mater? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Meningeal branch of internal carotid artery - Posterior cranial fossa

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is the incorrect pairing. The meningeal branch of the internal carotid artery doesn't primarily supply the dura mater of the posterior cranial fossa. The dura mater of the posterior cranial fossa is mainly supplied by branches from the vertebral arteries, such as the posterior meningeal artery.
  • The meningeal branches of Internal Carotid artery supply the anterior cranial fossa 
     

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Middle meningeal artery - Anterior cranial fossa: The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the maxillary artery. It is the most significant arterial supply to the dura mater. After entering the skull through the foramen spinosum, it typically divides into anterior and posterior branches. The anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery supplies the dura mater overlying the anterior cranial fossa.

 

Option B. Accessory meningeal branch of the maxillary artery - Middle cranial fossa: The accessory meningeal artery is a smaller branch that originates from the maxillary artery. It enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen ovale. This artery supplies the dura of the middle cranial fossa.

 

Option D. Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoid artery - Anterior cranial fossa: The anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries arise from the ophthalmic artery (a branch of the internal carotid artery). These arteries have meningeal branches that supply the dura mater in the anterior cranial fossa, specifically the region overlying the ethmoid bone and the frontal bone's adjacent parts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Summary of Blood supply to Dura

  1. Anterior cranial fossa
    1. By ethmoidal artery which is the branch of opthalmic artery which in tern is the branch of Internal carotid artery 
    2. Middle meningeal artery which is the branch of maxillary artery which in tern is the branch of external carotid artery
  2. Middle cranial fossa
    1. Accessory meningeal artery which is the branch of maxillary artery which in tern is the branch of external carotid artery
  3. Posterior Cranial fossa
    1. Meningeal branches from the branches of the vertebral artery.
       
  • The internal carotid artery (ICA) meningeal branch supply blood to the anterior cranial fossa.
  • The dura mater is supplied by meningeal arteries, which run along the inner periosteum (endosteum) of the skull and supply the following regions.

questions.text: A patient was prescribed escitalopram. Which of the following adverse effect is the least likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sialorrhea

 

Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). 

 

Sialorrhea is not typically associated with SSRIs. They are more likely to cause dry mouth. Sialorrhea is a common side effect of clozapine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nausea: Nausea is a common side effect of SSRIs.

 

Option B. Vivid dreams: Vivid dreams can occasionally be reported but are not the most common side effect.

 

Option C. Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia or other sexual side effects are also commonly associated with SSRIs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Side effects of SSRIs include:

 

  • Most common: Nausea
  • Most common long-term side effects: Sexual dysfunction including delayed orgasm, poor erection and low libido.
  • CNS side effects- Paradoxical anxiety, sedation, vivid dreams, sweating, seizures, EPSE etc.
  • QTc prolongation
  • Weight gain

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3156-3158

questions.text: Which of the following drug is not given in endometriosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Estradiol

 

Estradiol is avoided in the treatment of endometriosis because it can promote the growth of endometriotic lesions. Estradiol is a form of estrogen, which can stimulate the endometrial tissue and potentially exacerbate the symptoms and progression of endometriosis. The goal in managing endometriosis is to reduce estrogen levels or block estrogen’s effects to help resolve the lesions and alleviate symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medroxyprogesterone acetate: This is used in the treatment of endometriosis. Medroxyprogesterone acetate is a type of progesterone that helps create a state of endometrial atrophy, which can reduce the growth of endometriotic lesions.

 

Option B. Cabergoline: This drug is typically used to treat hyperprolactinemia but is not a standard treatment for endometriosis. While not commonly used in endometriosis management, its use is not contraindicated as estradiol is.

 

Option D. Letrozole: This is an aromatase inhibitor that lowers estrogen levels and is used in the treatment of endometriosis. By reducing estrogen levels, letrozole helps decrease the growth of endometriotic lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estradiol is avoided in the treatment of endometriosis because it can exacerbate the condition by promoting the growth of endometriotic lesions

choices.text: Mode is affected by extreme values
Mean is affected by extreme values
Median is calculated by overall observations
Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false for descriptors of central tendency? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Mode is affected by extreme values

 

  • Extreme values in a given dataset do not influence the mode.
  • Mode is the most frequent or most commonly occurring value in a distribution.
  • It is uninfluenced by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mean is affected by extreme values: This is true. Extreme values (outliers) can significantly affect the mean, making it an unreliable measure of central tendency in skewed distributions.

 

Option C. Median is calculated by overall observations: This is true. The median is determined by arranging all observations in order and finding the middle value, or the average of the two middle values if the number of observations is even.

 

Option D. Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor: This is true. The mode is applicable to qualitative data as it represents the most frequently occurring category or value.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mode is not affected by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data.
  • In contrast, the mean is affected by extreme values, and the median is a robust measure of central tendency that is calculated using overall observations.

choices.text: Cry of baby in the womb
Infection of vagina
Infection of uterus
Infection of both vagina and uterus

questions.text: What is vagitus uterinus? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cry of baby in the womb

 

  • Vagitus uterinus is the term used to describe the cry of a baby in the womb. It is a rare phenomenon but can occur if there is a rupture of the amniotic sac with air entry, allowing the baby to make crying sounds while still in utero.
  • Vagitus vaginus is the term for the cry of the baby in the vagina, which can be heard during delivery.
  • Infection of the vagina causes vaginitis.
  • Infection of the uterus may affect its layers, leading to conditions such as endometritis (infection of the endometrium), myometritis (infection of the myometrium), and perimetritis (infection of the perimetrium).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infection of vagina: Infection of the vagina causes vaginitis, which is not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Option C. Infection of uterus: Infection of the uterus can lead to endometritis, myometritis, or perimetritis, which are not related to the term vagitus uterinus.
