Option D. Infection of both vagina and uterus: Infection of both the vagina and uterus involves conditions such as vaginitis and endometritis/myometritis/perimetritis, which are not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vagitus uterinus refers to the cry of a baby in the womb, which is a rare phenomenon that can occur if there is a rupture of the amniotic sac with air entry.

questions.text:
John is a 45-year-old male who has been experiencing a bulge in his groin area that becomes more prominent when he coughs or strains. He has been diagnosed with an inguinal hernia and is scheduled for surgery. Before the procedure, the surgeon explains the condition and its potential complications. Which of the following statements about inguinal hernias are true? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by gonadal vessels
  2. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by Vas deferens
  3. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by rectus abdominis.
  4. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by iliopsoas
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 and 3

 

Medial border of the triangle of doom is bounded by Vas deferens and the Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bounded by lateral border of rectus abdominis.

 

Triangle of doom boundaries:

 

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

 

 

Myopectineal orifice of Frouchard boundaries:

 

  • Medially by the lateral border of the rectus sheath.
  • Above by the arched fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle.
  • Laterally by the iliopsoas muscle.
  • Below by the pectin pubis and fascia covering it.
  • All groin hernia- direct inguinal, indirect inguinal and femoral occur through this orifice.

questions.text: Which opening is present posterior to the marked structure in the image? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Eustachian tube

 

The marked structure appears to be the inferior turbinate, and:

 

  • The Eustachian tube opening is located 1 cm posterior to the posterior end of inferior turbinate
  • This represents the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube
  • It connects the middle ear with the nasopharynx
  • The opening appears as a vertical slit on the lateral wall of the nasopharynx
  • Forms an elevation called torus tubarius

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Onodi cell: This is a posterior ethmoid cell that extends superolateral to sphenoid sinus and is closely related to optic nerve. It is not located posterior to inferior turbinate.

Option C. Sphenopalatine foramen: This opening is located posterior to the middle turbinate (not inferior turbinate), about 1 cm behind its posterior end.

Option D. Sphenoid sinus: Opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, which is located above and posterior to superior turbinate, not inferior turbinate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Eustachian tube opening is located 1 cm posterior to the posterior end of inferior turbinate on the lateral wall of nasopharynx.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with the history of cough for one week. He also gives a history of hemoptysis for 1 month and fever for 4 days. The X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. RML consolidation

 

Explanation:

 

The X-ray shown above indicates consolidation due to presence of opacities in the right middle lobe silhouetting the right heart border along with the history of fever, cough and hemoptysis.

 

Silhouette sign

 

 

  • When the markings of heart are not visible – silhouette sign positive – localized to middle lobe /lingula
  • When the markings of heart are visible – silhouette sign negative – localized to lower lobe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RLL consolidation: Typically presents with obscuration of the right hemidiaphragm on X-ray, not the heart border.

 

Option C. RUL consolidation: Would more commonly show opacities in the upper right lung without affecting the silhouette of the heart.

 

Option D. Pericardial effusion: Would generally show an enlarged cardiac silhouette ("water bottle" sign), which is not evident in this image.

 

Educational Objective :

 

RML consolidation can be diagnosed when there is obscuration of the right heart border due to lung opacities in the middle lobe, accompanied by clinical symptoms of respiratory infection.

questions.text: Hamman sign is seen in: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Pneumomediastinum

 

Hamman sign, also known as Hamman's mediastinal crunch, is a crunching, rasping sound, synchronous with the heartbeat, heard over the precordium in cases of pneumomediastinum. This sign is caused by air in the mediastinum, which is the central compartment of the thoracic cavity. The presence of air in this area leads to a characteristic sound as the heart beats, which can be heard on auscultation.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Pneumoperitoneum: Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of air within the peritoneal cavity, usually due to gastrointestinal perforation. Clinical signs include guarding, rigidity, and air under the diaphragm visible on imaging. Hamman sign is not associated with pneumoperitoneum.

 

Option B. Pneumopericardium: This condition involves air within the pericardial cavity surrounding the heart. While it can cause similar auscultatory findings, it does not specifically present with Hamman sign.

 

Option D. Hydropneumothorax: This condition involves both air and fluid in the pleural space. A significant clinical finding here is straight-line dullness on percussion, not Hamman sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hamman sign, or Hamman's crunch, is a specific clinical sign heard in cases of pneumomediastinum, characterized by a crunching sound synchronous with the heartbeat due to the presence of air in the mediastinum.

questions.text: Cancer that least commonly spreads by lymphatic route is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Basal Cell Carcinoma

 

Basal cell carcinoma is a locally aggressive tumor that rarely spreads by the lymphatic route.

 

Mutations in sonic hedgehog pathway are associated with it.

 

Grossly, the most common pattern is a nodulo-ulcerative basal cell carcinoma in which a slow-growing small nodule undergoes central ulceration with pearly, rolled margins.

 

 

The occasional presence of melanin in this variant of nodular BCC (pigmented BCC. may lead to confusion with melanoma.

 

It occurs exclusively on hairy skin, the most common location (90%) being the face, usually above a line from the lobe of the ear to the corner of the mouth. The most common site is the inner canthus of the eye.

 

 

Basal cell carcinoma does not show lymphatic or hematogenous metastasis. It is primarily locally invasive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma often spreads via the lymphatic system, particularly when occurring in the skin or mucous membranes.

 

Option B. Merkel Cell Carcinoma: This is a rare and aggressive form of skin cancer that frequently metastasizes via the lymphatic system.

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma: Melanoma is known for its high metastatic potential, often spreading through both lymphatic and hematogenous routes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basal cell carcinoma is primarily a locally invasive tumor that rarely spreads via the lymphatic or hematogenous routes, distinguishing it from other more aggressive skin cancers.

questions.text: Match the following drugs with the receptors they act upon: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2

 

 

Other Options:

 

A-3. Mirabegron acts on β3 receptors. Mirabegron is a β3 adrenergic receptor agonist used for the treatment of bladder incontinence by relaxing the detrusor muscle during the storage phase of the urinary bladder fill-void cycle.

 

B-4. Indacaterol acts on β2 receptors. Indacaterol is a long-acting β2 adrenergic agonist used in the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

 

C-1. Betaxolol acts on β1 receptors. Betaxolol is a β1 selective blocker used in the treatment of hypertension and glaucoma.

 

D-2. Isoproterenol acts on β1 β2 receptors. Isoproterenol is a non-selective β adrenergic agonist with no α action, used in the treatment of bradycardia and heart block.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypothermia

 

  • Paradoxical undressing is seen in hypothermia victims.
  • The victims, despite low environmental temperatures, paradoxically remove their clothes due to a sudden feeling of warmth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heat stress: Heat stress leads to symptoms such as heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke, characterized by elevated body temperature, dehydration, and sometimes loss of consciousness. It does not cause paradoxical undressing.

 

Option B. Voyeurism: Voyeurism is a psychiatric condition where an individual derives sexual pleasure from observing unsuspecting people who are naked, undressing, or engaging in sexual activities. It is unrelated to hypothermia or paradoxical undressing.

 

Option D. LSD overdose: LSD overdose can cause hallucinations, altered mental status, and sensory distortions. While individuals may engage in bizarre behaviors, paradoxical undressing is not a recognized symptom of LSD overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paradoxical undressing occurs in hypothermia victims who, despite experiencing extremely low temperatures, remove their clothing due to a sudden and misleading sensation of warmth.

questions.text: A middle-aged housewife consumed rodenticide powder and presented with K+ levels of 2.5meq. On examination, irregular pulse with muscle paralysis is present. ECG shows ventricular ectopics. What is the suspected poison? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Barium carbonate

 

The above clinical scenario with a presentation of hypokalemia, cardiac arrhythmia, and paralysis after consumption of rodenticide poison is caused by Barium carbonate.

 

Barium carbonate is used in rat poison and acts as a local corrosive irritant that, after absorption, primarily affects the muscles, including the heart muscles.

 

  • The initial symptoms manifest as gastrointestinal distress like nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
  • It subsequently progresses to muscle cramps, stiffness, pupil dilation, paralysis of the tongue and larynx, and vertigo.
  • The early impact on the heart can lead to increased blood pressure, slow and irregular pulse, and in severe cases, potential cardiac arrest.
  • Notable changes also include loss of reflexes and muscle paralysis.

 

Treatment involves:

 

  1. Gastric lavage to remove the contents and administration of either sodium sulfate or magnesium sulfate solution to precipitate the barium as an insoluble sulfate.
  2. Intravenous administration of 10 mL of 10% sodium sulfate every 15 minutes to convert the soluble barium salt into insoluble sulfate.
  3. Purging with magnesium sulfate and repeated bowel lavage.
  4. Symptomatic management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aluminium phosphide (ALP): This is a solid fumigant pesticide and rodenticide that releases phosphine gas, a toxic agent, which leads to inhibition of the electron transport chain and severe toxicity. It does not cause hypokalemia but causes other symptoms like cardiac arrhythmias, congestive heart failure, and death due to cardiogenic shock.

 

Option B. Zinc phosphide: This rodenticide can cause symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. However, its toxicity is generally less severe compared to aluminium phosphide, but it does not cause the hypokalemia seen in the clinical presentation.

 

Option D. Warfarin tablets: Warfarin is an anticoagulant used in some rat poisons, but it is not associated with hypokalemia. It acts primarily by affecting clotting factors, leading to bleeding tendencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barium carbonate poisoning leads to hypokalemia, muscle paralysis, and cardiac arrhythmias, requiring urgent treatment with gastric lavage and sulfate administration to prevent fatal complications.

choices.text: CCK - I cells, Duodenum and jejunum
Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum

questions.text: Which of the subsequent pairs are inaccurately matched? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum

 

Motilin is a gastrointestinal hormone produced by enterochromaffin cells and Mo cells (Not M cells) present in the stomach, small intestine, and colon.

M cells, or microfold cells, are specialized epithelial cells in the gut-associated lymphoid tissue (GALT) that play a crucial role in initiating mucosal immune responses, it does not release Motilin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrin - G cells, Antrum: Correct. Gastrin is produced by G cells located in the antrum of the stomach and stimulates H+ secretion by parietal cells.

 

Option B. Secretin - S cells, Duodenum: Correct. Secretin is produced by S cells in the duodenum and decreases gastric acid secretion while increasing pancreatic bicarbonate secretion.

 

Option C. CCK - I cells, Duodenum and jejunum: Correct. Cholecystokinin (CCK) is produced by I cells in the duodenum and jejunum, increasing pancreatic enzyme secretion and gallbladder contraction while decreasing gastric emptying and relaxing the sphincter of Oddi.

 

Option D. Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum: Incorrect. Motilin is produced by enterochromaffin cells and Mo cells in the stomach, small intestine, and colon, not exclusively by M cells in the duodenum and jejunum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GIT HORMONES

 

  • Gastrin – G cell at antrum. Acts on Parietal cells stimulate the H+ K+ ATPase.
  • Secretin – S cells at Duodenum. Decrease gastric acid secretion and Increase pancreatic HCO3- secretion.
  • CCK-PZ – I cells in duodenum and jejunum. Increase pancreatic HCO3- secretion, Increase gall bladder contraction, Decrease gastric emptying and increase sphincter of Oddi relaxation.
  • GIP – K cells in duodenum and jejunum. Decrease H+ secretion and increase insulin release.
  • Motilin – Mo cells in small intestine. Produces migrating motor complexes (MMCs).

questions.text: Match the following tumours with their treatment choices: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-a, 2-c, 3-b, 4-d

 

 

1. GIANT CELL TUMOR (Osteoclastoma)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Radiological features: Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with  hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

2. OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.
    • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic  bone may be seen outside the involved bone.
       
  • Management:
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.
       

3. SIMPLE BONE CYST

 

  • Simple bone cysts are a common pseudotumor of bone.
  • They are found in the proximal humerus in 50% of cases and in the upper femur in 25%.
  • The calcaneus and pelvis are also uniquely common locations.
  • Patients are asymptomatic until a pathologic fracture occurs.
  • Radiographs typically show a solitary cyst that is centrally located in the metaphyseal area and has marked thinning of the adjacent cortical bone and a pseudoloculated appearance.
  • If there is associated fracture, radiographs may show the characteristic “fallen leaf” sign.
  • In weight-bearing bones, such as the proximal femur, lesions should be treated aggressively.
  • Management:
    • Initial management usually involves aspiration/injection with either bone marrow or corticosteroid.
    • The injections are carried out with bone biopsy needles and are repeated three to five times at intervals of 2 to 3 months, depending on the radiographic response.
    • Curettage and bone grafting may also be an effective modality.

 

4. OSTEOID OSTEOMA

 

  • The most common benign osteoid-forming tumor is the osteoid osteoma, accounting for 10% of all benign bone tumors.
  • The proximal femur is the most common location.
  • Dull, aching, nocturnal pain is characteristic, and it is commonly relieved entirely by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) secondary to a high concentration of prostaglandins in the nidus.
  • Radiographic Feature:
    • Central, lytic nidus usually 1 cm or less in diameter. The more common cortically-based lesion exhibits extensive reactive sclerosis, creating a fusiform bulge on the bone surface. If the nidus is close to, or actually in, a joint, as in a femoral neck lesion, the resulting reactive synovitis may mimic a pyarthrosis or rheumatoid arthritis.
    • Technetium bone scans are invariably positive. A CT scan is recommended to better anatomically locate the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.
    • In the spine, the typical location for an osteoid osteoma is in the posterior elements.
       
  • Management:
    • Many cases of osteoid osteoma are stage 1 lesions and can be treated symptomatically with aspirin or NSAIDs until they spontaneously resolve. If the patient fails such treatment, intervention is warranted.
    • CT-guided radiofrequency ablation has emerged as the preferred treatment modality in many cases.
    • If open surgical excision is undertaken, the entire nidus must be eradicated.

questions.text: Histological examination of a cervical lymph node biopsy is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

The histological image shows a lot of pink areas, indicative of necrosis, and an inflammatory infiltrate. These features are suggestive of caseous necrosis, surrounded by a ring of lymphocytes, which is characteristic of tuberculosis. Tuberculosis often affects the cervical lymph nodes, leading to their enlargement and caseous necrosis, commonly referred to as "matting" of the lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sarcoidosis: Incorrect. Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas and commonly affects the lungs and hilar lymph nodes, not typically the cervical lymph nodes.

 

Option C. Langerhans cell histiocytosis: Incorrect. This condition would show Langerhans cells (which have a characteristic appearance) and is not associated with the caseous necrosis seen in the image.

 

Option D. Hodgkin lymphoma: Incorrect. Hodgkin lymphoma presents with Reed Sternberg cells and does not show caseous necrosis. Although Hodgkin lymphoma can cause cervical lymph node enlargement, it does not fit the granulomatous inflammation pattern shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of caseous necrosis and a ring of lymphocytes in the histological examination of cervical lymph nodes strongly suggests tuberculosis as the diagnosis.

 

Histological Hallmarks of TB in Lymph Nodes:

 

  • Caseating granulomas (granulomas with central necrosis)
  • Surrounding epithelioid histiocytes, Langhans giant cells, and lymphocytes
  • Necrosis is a key differentiator from sarcoidosis (which has non-caseating granulomas)

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve that arises from the marked part? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Abducens nerve

 

The image shows the abducens nerve.

 

Origin: The abducens nerve originates in the pons. Its fibers arise from the abducens nucleus, which is located in the dorsal pons near the floor of the fourth ventricle.

 

Exit Point: It emerges from the ventral surface of the brainstem at the junction between the pons and the medulla, in the groove between the pons and the pyramid of the medulla.

 

Function: It innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oculomotor Nerve (III)

 

  • Origin: The oculomotor nerve originates in the anterior aspect of the midbrain. Specifically, its fibers arise from the oculomotor nucleus, which is located in the superior colliculus of the midbrain.
  • Exit Point: After emerging from the midbrain, it exits the brainstem at the level of the interpeduncular fossa (the space between the cerebral peduncles).
  • Function: It innervates most of the muscles controlling eye movements. It also contains parasympathetic fibers that are involved in pupil constriction and the lens's accommodation.

 

Option B. Glossopharyngeal Nerve (IX)

 

  • Origin: The glossopharyngeal nerve arises from the medulla oblongata, specifically from the postolivary sulcus, which lies lateral to the olive.
  • Exit Point: It exits the brainstem in a groove between the olive and the inferior cerebellar peduncle, alongside the vagus (X) and accessory (XI) nerves.
  • Function: It has several roles, including taste from the posterior third of the tongue, sensation from the upper pharynx, and innervation of the stylopharyngeus muscle.

 

Option D. Facial Nerve (VII)

 

  • Origin: The facial nerve arises from the pons. Specifically, its fibers come from the facial nerve nucleus.
  • Exit Point: It emerges from the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle, between the pons and the medulla. It exits lateral to the abducens nerve and medial to the vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII).
  • Function: The facial nerve controls the muscles of facial expression. It also has taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and carries parasympathetic fibers to salivary and lacrimal glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The abducens nerve, also known as cranial nerve VI, arises from the abducens nucleus in the pontomedullary junction, which is located in the lower part of the pons and upper part of the medulla oblongata in the brainstem. It exits the brainstem at the junction of the pons and medulla oblongata and travels through the cavernous sinus to innervate the lateral rectus muscle of the eye. Its main function is to control eye movement and allow for horizontal gaze.

questions.text: Which of these is not a feature of Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory rate > 22/ minute and PaCO2 <35mmHg

 

  • This statement does not align with the criteria for SIRS. In SIRS, an elevated respiratory rate (tachypnea) is defined as a respiratory rate greater than 20 breaths per minute or an arterial carbon dioxide partial pressure (PaCO2) less than 32 mmHg. Therefore, the option presented combines an elevated respiratory rate with an abnormally low PaCO2, which is not part of the SIRS criteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features of Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) are:

 

  • Fever (body temperature >38°C) or temperature <36°C.
  • Tachycardia (heart rate >90 beats per minute).
  • Tachypnea (respiratory rate >20 breaths per minute or arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO2) < 32 mm Hg).
  • Leukocytosis (white blood cell count >12,000 cells/mm³), leukopenia (white blood cell count <4,000 cells/mm³), or the presence of >10% immature neutrophils (band forms) in the blood.
  • Other signs of systemic inflammation such as elevated levels of C-reactive protein (CRP) or procalcitonin.

questions.text: The structure that divides the liver in Couinaud's classification system is? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Portal vein

 

The structure that divides the liver in Couinaud's classification system is the portal vein.

 

The portal vein is a significant vessel that delivers blood from the gastrointestinal tract, spleen, pancreas, and gallbladder to the liver.

 

In the context of Couinaud's classification, the liver is divided into right and left lobes by the main portal vein. Further segmentation divides each lobe into individual segments based on the branches of the portal vein. As such, the portal vein is the primary structure used in Couinaud's system to determine liver segmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatic artery: The hepatic artery provides oxygen-rich blood to the liver. While it is part of the portal triad and serves individual liver segments, it is not the primary structure used to define the segments in Couinaud's classification. The segmentation is based on the portal vein's distribution, although the hepatic artery's branches supply the respective segments concurrently.

 

Option C. Bile duct: The bile ducts are responsible for transporting bile produced in the liver to the gallbladder for storage or directly to the small intestine for digestion. Similar to the hepatic artery, while bile ducts are part of the portal triad and serve individual liver segments, they aren't the primary structure used for segmentation in the Couinaud's system.

 

Option D. Cystic duct: The cystic duct connects the gallbladder to the common bile duct. It does not have a direct role in dividing the liver into its segments and is unrelated to Couinaud's classification system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Illustration of the segmental anatomy of the liver based on the third-order portal vein branching (Couinaud's classification system) and the portal vein and hepatic vein branches.

 

IVC: inferior vena cava and PV: portal vein.

choices.text: It should not be given with erythropoietin
It is given by intravenous route
It is more immunogenic than iron dextran
A single bolus dose is enough for treatment of iron deficiency anemia

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding iron isomaltoside? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is given by intravenous route

 

Explanation:

 

Iron isomaltoside is an intravenous iron preparation that can be given via IV route over approximately 30 minutes. It is characterized by having a very low risk of allergic reactions compared to other IV iron preparations. The drug can be administered in high doses, typically requiring 2-3 doses for complete treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It should not be given with erythropoietin: Incorrect. Iron isomaltoside can be safely given with erythropoietin. It's iron ferromoxitol that should be avoided with erythropoietin.

 

Option C. It is more immunogenic than iron dextran: Incorrect. Iron isomaltoside has very low immunogenicity and is less immunogenic than iron dextran.

 

Option D. A single bolus dose is enough for treatment: Incorrect. Usually 2-3 doses are required for complete treatment, though occasionally one dose might be sufficient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron isomaltoside is an IV iron preparation characterized by low immunogenicity, compatibility with erythropoietin, and typically requires 2-3 doses for complete treatment.

 

 

Injectable Iron

  • Preparations of injectable iron are:
    • Iron Dextran-Can be given IV as well as IM
    • Iron Sorbital citrate (Used im olnly)
  • Intramuscular iron is given by Z-tract technique to avoid pigmentation

 

Indication of injectable iron:

  • Oral iron cannot be given e.g.
    • Malabsorption
    • Not tolerated (due to GI symptoms)
  • Given with erythropoietin
    • Erythropoietin will stinulate RBC formation and will unmask any iron deficiency 
  • Dose of injectable iron = 4.3 x Hb deficit (g/dl) x body weight (kg)
    • This formula includes the iron required for replenishment of stores also.

questions.text:
Which of the following investigations are not used for diagnosing osteoporosis?(INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. DEXA
  2. Bone scan
  3. Quantitative CT
  4. Chemical analysis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) II, IV are correct

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards)
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: 
    • Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Estrogen
    • Bisphosphonates – Increases hip fracture.
    • Calcitonin
    • Low dose PTH – Stimulates osteoblasts.

 

Other Options:

 

  • A bone scan helps to examine any irregularities in the bone. Sometimes, these bone irregularities may indicate either infection or cancer disease. In addition, it can also help to detect arthritis and bone fractures.

  • Chemical analysis test will not show any diagnostic change because the serum calcium, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase levels remains normal in osteoporosis. The problem with osteoporosis is of bone quality and not its chemical makeup.

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • DEXA scan is the investigation of choice.
  • Quantitative CT is a bone mineral density (BMD) measurement technique in which the CT scanner is calibrated using solid phantoms (made of calcium hydroxyapatite, representing various bone mineral densities) placed under the patient in a pad. With this calibration, the Hounsfield units are converted to bone mineral density values. The technique can be used for both peripheral and central BMD measurements, with lumbar spine and hip being preferred locations.
  • DEXA measures the bone mineral density of both the outer (cortical) shell and the inner (trabecular) structure of the bone. QCT, on the other hand, measures only the inner part. Because of this difference, QCT studies of the spine show a lower T-score than a DEXA would.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was diagnosed with intussusception and is taken up for surgery. The surgeon found multiple polyps and sent the resected section for histopathology. The image is given below. What is the type of lesion? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hamartomatous polyp

 

The image and clinical scenario point towards a hamartomatous polyp, particularly because of the patient's young age and the finding of multiple polyps. Hamartomatous polyps are generally solitary lesions but can be multiple in certain syndromes, such as Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and juvenile polyposis syndrome, which are more common in children and adolescents.

 

Hamartomatous polyps are benign, disorganized growths of tissue that are normally found in the location where they arise. In the context of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, these polyps are associated with an increased risk of intussusception due to their size and location in the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubulo-villous adenoma: This type of adenoma has both tubular and villous features and is typically found in older adults, with a higher risk of malignant transformation.

 

Option C. Villous Adenoma: These are the most dangerous types of adenomas due to their higher potential for malignancy, but they are usually seen in older patients and have a distinctive villous histological appearance.

 

Option D. Hyperplastic polyp: Generally benign and more common in adults, hyperplastic polyps are typically located in the distal colon and rectum and are not associated with intussusception or multiple polyps in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1557

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with neck swelling as shown. The swelling moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion. What is your diagnosis?  (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thyroglossal cyst

 

Among the given options, thyroglossal cyst is the only neck swelling which is midline, moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion. This is because the thyroid gland is fixed to the hyoid.

 

Thyroglossal cysts are cystic swellings that form from the remnants of the thyroglossal duct, which is a duct that connects the developing thyroid gland to the tongue during embryonic development. These cysts often move with deglutition or tongue protrusion and are typically located in the midline of the neck, as seen in the provided image.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branchial cyst: Branchial cysts are typically located along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle (upper and middle third) and do not move with deglutition. They are congenital and arise from remnants of branchial arches.

 

 

Option B. Cystic hygroma: Cystic hygromas are usually found in the neck and are also congenital, usually in posterior triangle. They are caused by lymphatic malformation and do not typically move with deglutition.

 

 

Option D. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy refers to enlarged lymph nodes in the neck. While lymph nodes can sometimes be palpable in the neck, they do not usually move with deglutition and are not typically cystic in nature.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other neck swellings that move with deglutition are:

 

  • Thyroid swellings
  • Subhyoid bursitis
  • Dermoid cysts attached to the hyoid bone

 

However, amongst these only the thyroglossal cyst moves with tongue protrusion. This occurs because the duct extends from the foramen caecum of tongue to the isthmus of the gland.

 

Sistrunk's operation is the procedure performed to excise the cyst and prevent a recurrence. It involves excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, along with removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum along with the core of tissue on either side.

questions.text: The type of fibers present in the fornix are? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Association and commisural fibers

 

All of the fornix's fibres are association fibres, with the exception of the hippocampal commissure, which possesses commissural fibres. As a result, option A—both association and commissural fibers—is the best response.

 

Association fibers connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere whereas commissural fibers connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

 

Fornix arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mamillary body of the hypothalamus. Its blood supply - anterior cerebral artery.

 

Note: The function of the commissure of the fornix is to connect the hippocampal formations of the two sides.

 

 

  • The commissural fibers or transverse fibers: are axons that connect the two hemispheres of the brain.
  • Association fibers: connect regions within the same hemisphere of the brain
  • Projection fibers: connect each region to other parts of the brain or to the spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Association and Projection fibers: Projection fibers: These fibers connect the cerebral cortex to the lower brain regions and spinal cord. They are mainly involved in conveying information between the cerebral cortex and other parts of the CNS. The fornix doesn't primarily contain projection fibers; its main constituents are association and commissural fibers.

 

Option C. Commissural and Projection fibers: As previously stated, while the fornix contains commissural fibers, it doesn't mainly contain projection fibers.

 

Option D. Association fibers: Association fibers, as mentioned, connect different parts of the same hemisphere. The fornix does contain association fibers, but it's not limited to just these; it also has commissural fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fornix contains both association fibers (linking parts of the hippocampus to other regions within the same hemisphere) and commissural fibers (connecting the hippocampi of the two hemispheres).

 

Association fibers: These fibers connect different parts of the same hemisphere. Their function is to enable communication between different cortical areas within the same cerebral hemisphere.

 

Commissural fibers: These are axons that connect one cerebral hemisphere to the other. Their primary function is to allow the two hemispheres to communicate with each other. The corpus callosum is the most significant group of commissural fibers, but the fornix also contains commissural fibers. Specifically, fibers from the fornix contribute to the hippocampal commissure, which connects the two hippocampi of the right and left hemispheres.

questions.text: Match the following therapeutic methods used in the management of psoriasis with their possible side effects? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d

 

Correct matches

 

 

PUVA (Psoralen and Ultraviolet A)

 

  • Over 90% of cases of psoriasis are successfully treated with PUVA.
  • Both acute (erythema, blistering) and chronic side effects are associated with it.
  • Use of PUVA for an extended period is linked to non-melanoma skin cancer development (squamous cell and basal cell cancers).

 

Cyclosporine

 

  • Cyclosporine usage is primarily linked to metabolic issues, a possible increased risk of malignancy, and renal impairment (decreased GFR).
  • Due to its nephrotoxic effects, it is now uncommonly used for the maintenance of psoriasis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common therapies for psoriasis with their potential side effects:

 

  • PUVA increases the risk of skin cancer (1-c),
  • Cyclosporine is nephrotoxic (2-b),
  • Methotrexate can act as an abortifacient (3-a), and
  • Acitretin is teratogenic and can cause mucositis (4-d).

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 page no 35.26-28

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page 3402

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came to the OPD with complaints of backache. On examination, her eyes and pinna revealed blackish discoloration. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Alkaptonuria

 

Explanation:

 

Intervertebral disc calcification is seen in the image suggestive of alkaptonuria.

 

Deficiency: Homogentisic oxidase

 

Hyperpigmentation of ears and eyes suggestive of ochronosis is a clue. It is seen due to excessive build-up of homogentisic acid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis): Features ossification along the anterolateral aspect of at least four contiguous vertebral bodies, often with a "candle wax dripping" appearance, distinct from the findings in alkaptonuria.

 

Option B. Fluorosis: Typically presents with increased bone density and ossification of interosseous ligaments, not specifically associated with hyperpigmentation or the disc calcifications shown.

 

Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis: Characterized by a "bamboo spine" appearance due to bony fusion, seen in younger patients (less than 50 years old), which does not typically include hyperpigmentation or the type of disc calcification seen in alkaptonuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alkaptonuria - Is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisic oxidase
  • Fluorosis – Increased bone density with interosseous ligament ossification 
  • DISH VS   Ankylosing spondylitis

questions.text: What is the cause of tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Unburnt particles  

 

  • Tattooing is a term used to describe the punctate abrasions observed when skin comes into contact with partially burned or unburned grains of gunpowder.
  • They are also called stippling or peppering. This is seen up to 50 cm of firing
  • They are seen in near (30-50cm) to mid-range of shooting

 

Firearm injuries:

 

 

Blackening – due to deposit of smoke

 

 

 

Grease collar - due to the deposition of the lubricant of the bullet in the tissues

 

Burn injuries - occur due to flame released during the firing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Smoke: Causes blackening, not tattooing.

 

Option C. Impact: Refers to the force of the bullet causing tissue damage but does not explain tattooing.

 

Option D. Muzzle impression: Occurs when the muzzle of the firearm makes contact with the skin, leaving an impression, but does not cause tattooing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet is caused by unburnt particles of gunpowder embedding into the skin.

choices.text: To be done in lateral recumbent position
The bevel should face upwards while inserting the needle.

questions.text: Regarding the procedure done with the needle shown below, which of the following is false? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coagulopathy is not a contraindication.

 

The image depicts a spinal needle used primarily for lumbar puncture (LP), a procedure where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected from the lumbar cistern. The procedure can be conducted in either the lateral recumbent position or sitting position, depending on the patient's comfort and the physician's preference. The bevel orientation during insertion affects the dural fibers; positioning it parallel (typically upwards) minimizes dural fiber tearing and the subsequent likelihood of post-lumbar puncture headaches. Importantly, coagulopathy is a significant contraindication for lumbar puncture due to the increased risk of spinal hematoma and severe complications associated with bleeding around the spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To be done in lateral recumbent position: This is true and is one of the standard positions for performing an LP.

 

Option B. Breath holding is not necessary: During LP, patients are advised to breathe normally to avoid increases in intra-abdominal and intrathoracic pressure, which could affect CSF dynamics.

 

Option C. The bevel should face upwards while inserting the needle: This is a recommended practice to reduce the risk of post-procedure complications, such as a post-dural puncture headache.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coagulopathy is a contraindication for lumbar puncture due to the risk of bleeding and potential for serious complications, contrary to the incorrect statement provided. Always assess the patient’s coagulation status prior to performing an LP.

questions.text: The procedure displayed below is? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Orogastric tube insertion.

 

The procedure depicted in the image is orogastric tube insertion. This involves placing a tube through the mouth (orally) and advancing it down into the stomach. Orogastric tubes are commonly used in pediatric patients for several purposes:

 

  • Enteral rehydration: In children with mild-to-moderate dehydration, an orogastric tube can be used to facilitate enteral rehydration, allowing for fluid administration directly into the stomach.
  • Nutritional support: For children who are severely ill or have significant dehydration, orogastric tubes can also be used for nutritional support by delivering necessary nutrients and medications directly to the stomach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubation: Intubation involves placing a tube into the trachea to maintain an open airway and is primarily used in situations where airway protection or mechanical ventilation is required. This is not the procedure shown in the image.

 

Option B. Nasogastric tube insertion: Nasogastric tube insertion is similar to orogastric tube insertion, but the tube is inserted through the nose instead of the mouth. While both procedures aim to reach the stomach, the entry point distinguishes them.

 

Option D. Oropharyngeal airway insertion: Oropharyngeal airways are devices inserted into the mouth to prevent the tongue from obstructing the airway, usually during anesthesia or in unconscious patients. This is not the procedure shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orogastric tube insertion involves placing a tube through the mouth into the stomach and is used for rehydration and nutritional support in pediatric patients, particularly those with dehydration or severe illness.

questions.text: What does the ECG show? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) P pulmonale

 

The ECG presented shows tall P waves in lead II, which are characteristic of P pulmonale. P pulmonale refers to the presence of abnormally tall P waves in the ECG, usually greater than 2.5 mm in height in lead II. This finding indicates right atrial enlargement, which is commonly associated with pulmonary conditions such as pulmonary hypertension. Right atrial enlargement occurs due to increased pressure or volume overload in the right atrium, often secondary to lung diseases that lead to increased pulmonary artery pressures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrical alternans: Electrical alternans is characterized by alternating amplitude or direction of the QRS complexes in the ECG. It is often associated with large pericardial effusions and is not indicated by the tall P waves seen in this ECG.

 

Option C. Ventricular bigeminy: Ventricular bigeminy refers to a rhythm where every normal beat is followed by a premature ventricular contraction (PVC). The ECG would show alternating normal QRS complexes with PVCs, which is not seen here.

 

Option D. Improper calibration: Improper calibration of an ECG machine would result in uniformly abnormal waves across all leads, which does not match the specific tall P waves observed in lead II in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

P pulmonale, indicated by tall P waves greater than 2.5 mm in lead II, signifies right atrial enlargement commonly due to pulmonary hypertension or other pulmonary conditions leading to increased right atrial pressure.

questions.text: Diabetic drug that should be stopped immediately with a creatinine of 5.6mg/dl? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metformin

 

Metformin, a commonly prescribed medication for type 2 diabetes, primarily works by reducing hepatic glucose production. It is contraindicated in patients with significant renal impairment due to the risk of lactic acidosis, a potentially life-threatening condition.

 

It is to be stopped if creatinine level >1.5mg/dl in men and >1.4mg/dl in women

 

MOA of metformin- reduces hepatic glucose production.

 

Adverse effects - nausea, diarrhea, lactic acidosis, vit b12 deficiency

 

Contraindications:  serum creatinine 1.5 (in males)/ 1.4(females)

 

GFR<30ml/min, Unstable CHF, Hepatic failure, Acidosis, Hospitalized patients who cannot take anything orally

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Linagliptin: This is a DPP-4 inhibitor, which does not require adjustment for kidney disease and is not directly harmful in renal failure.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: A beta-blocker used for cardiovascular conditions including hypertension; not directly affected by renal function in terms of drug safety, though dosing may need adjustment.

 

Option D. Insulin: Often required in higher doses or with careful monitoring in renal impairment due to decreased insulin clearance, but not contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metformin should be discontinued in patients with a creatinine level above 1.5 mg/dL for men and 1.4 mg/dL for women, or a GFR below 30 mL/min to avoid the risk of lactic acidosis, especially in the context of significant renal impairment.

choices.text: Extend knee and plantar flex foot
Flex knee and plantar flex foot

questions.text: A pregnant woman has cramps in her legs. What will you suggest to her to relieve the pain? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extend knee and dorsiflex foot

 

Explanation:

 

To relieve leg cramps, the recommended technique is to:

 

  • Extend the knee: Straightening the leg helps in relieving tension and alleviating the cramp.
  • Dorsiflex the foot: This involves pulling the toes towards the shin, which stretches the calf muscles and helps in reducing the cramp.

 

Leg cramps during pregnancy are commonly caused by factors such as deficiencies in serum calcium, elevated serum phosphorus, or increased pressure on the leg veins. Stretching and adjusting the foot position can provide immediate relief from cramps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flex knee and dorsiflex foot: Flexing the knee while dorsiflexing the foot can help in some cases, but extending the knee is generally more effective in relieving cramp pain.

 

Option C. Extend knee and plantar flex foot: Plantar flexion (pointing the toes downward) can actually exacerbate calf cramps. Extending the knee while performing plantar flexion is not as effective for cramp relief.

 

Option D. Flex knee and plantar flex foot: Flexing the knee while performing plantar flexion will likely increase the cramp discomfort. This position may not provide effective relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To relieve leg cramps during pregnancy, extend the knee and dorsiflex the foot.

 

Ref: https://americanpregnancy.org/healthy-pregnancy/pregnancy-health-wellness/leg-cramps-during-pregnancy

questions.text: The data which best explains the difference between the highest and the lowest values is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Range

 

Range gives the difference between the highest and lowest values in a given set of data.

 

For example, in a dataset of students' marks, if the highest score is 100 and the lowest is 51, the range would be 49.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Variance: Variance (or SD2) is the mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution. It measures how far data is spread out.

 

Option B. Coefficient of variation: The coefficient of variation (CV) is used to compare the variability. It expresses the It is unitless and helps compare variability across different datasets.

 

CV= SD/ mean x 100

 

Option D. Interquartile range: Quartiles divide the distribution into four equal groups. The difference between the mid-values of each quartile gives the interquartile range, which measures the spread of the middle 50% of data.

 

Educational Objective:


Range is a simple measure that explains the spread between the highest and lowest values in a dataset, making it useful for quickly understanding data dispersion.
